question_text: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for a painful lesion inside his mouth.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is pemphigus vulgaris (Option B), a rare autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by blisters and erosions caused by detachment of adhesions between stratified squamous epithelial cells (acantholysis) on skin and mucous membranes. Oropharyngeal erosions are almost always present in pemphigus vulgaris and are frequently the presenting manifestation. The trunk, including the axillae, scalp, and neck, are often involved. Affected skin has flaccid blisters that generally develop on noninflamed skin; are readily broken; and progress to large, weeping, denuded areas. NSAIDs, rifampin, cephalosporins, captopril, and penicillamine have been associated with this condition.
